title: Anika Wells ‘bending the rules’ and spending big on the government credit card
description: Sky News host Andrew Bolt says Prime Minister Anthony Albanese needs to sack Communications Minister Anika Wells for “spending big” on herself with the government credit card.  Mr Bolt said Anika Wells was “bending the rules” to use taxpayer money for her own personal gain.  “There's one particular item of that spending that really sticks in my throat, this dinner that she had in Paris, nearly 600 euros or 1,000 dollars, and not to impress any foreign official, it was just dinner for Wells, two Australian public servants with her and the Australian ambassador.”

title: ‘Will not lay down weapons’: Hamas continues violating Trump’s peace plan
description: Sky News host Sharri Markson analyses Hamas violating United States President Donald Trump’s peace plan.  Ms Markson sat down with Anti-Defamation League International Affairs Senior Vice President Marina Rosenberg to go over the terrorist organisation’s refusal to lay down arms.  Ms Rosenberg said Hamas is fighting to destroy the only Jewish state that exists.

title: ‘Gleefully spending public money’: Anika Wells scrutinised over expenses
description: Sky News host Sharri Markson sits down with Shadow Finance Minister James Paterson to go over Communications Minister Anika Wells’ travel and expense debacle.

title: ‘Fire breaks around properties’: New South Wales can learn from earlier bushfire seasons
description: New South Wales Nationals Leader Gurmesh Singh says New South Wales can learn from earlier bushfires about fire breaks around properties, towns, and cities.   This comes as New South Wales bushfires have claimed the life of a firefighter.   “One of the big lessons out of the 2019 and 2020 bushfires were that we need to start having a really mature conversation around what it looks like in terms of fire breaks around properties,” Mr Singh told Sky News host Paul Murray.

title: ‘In the midst of tragedy’: NSW bushfires test the state’s hazard readiness
description: New South Wales Nationals Leader Gurmesh Singh expresses concern over New South Wales’ readiness for the upcoming fire season.  “Those fires are still burning,” Mr Singh told Sky News host Paul Murray.  “This is not just an RFS issue; this is across all different land tenures that the state government has.”

title: Right-wingers labelled a ‘danger to kids’ in UK
description: Sky News host James Macpherson highlights how right-wingers have been labelled a “danger to kids” in the UK.

title: Poll indicates only 29 per cent of parents to ‘fully’ enforce social media ban for kids
description: Sky News host Paul Murray analyses the social media ban set to kick in this week.

title: ‘That’s strange’: ABC given ‘platinum’ status by ACON
description: Sky News host Freya Leach says it’s “strange” the ABC has been given platinum status by ACON.   “If you’re looking for a new place to get a job, you might want to check out the ABC, because they’ve just been given the platinum employer rating by ACON … an LGBTQI-plus lobby group,” Ms Leach said.  “ACON gives out these awards every year to employers that reach the pinnacle of inclusivity.”

title: Labor ‘failed to deliver’ on cost of living promises
description: Sky News host Paul Murray analyses the “reality” behind Treasurer Jim Chalmers’ “election bribe” as his promises remain unfulfilled.  “They had failed to deliver on the central promise of the previous election, another lie,” Mr Murray said.  “They doubled-down again going into the last election, and it meant it was a $75 a quarter, $25 a month but all of it ended up costing the best part of seven almost eight billion dollars.”

title: ‘Power prices still on the rise’: Australia’s energy debate continues
description: Sky News host Chris Kenny sits down with Coalition for Conservation Founder Cristina Talacko to go over Labor’s “delusional” and “deliberately deceptive” energy debacle.  According to an article in The Financial Review, ‘Australia’s insistence that an advanced industrial economy can be powered primarily by intermittent renewables within a decade has shifted from policy position to political identity’.   The article also states, ‘evidence is treated as threat rather than guidance’.

title: ‘In reality’: Tariff-hit countries may not sympathise with Trump’s national security strategy
description: The Australian’s Foreign Editor Greg Sheridan sits down with Sky News host Andrew Bolt to analyse the US’ national security strategy amid concerns relationships with tariff-imposed countries have waned.  “The US has in the last year imposes insane punitive tariffs on India and it has driven India into the arms both of Vladimir Putin and of China,” Mr Sheridan told Sky News host Andrew Bolt.  “This is because Narendra Modi disagreed with Trump that Trump had solved the India-Pakistan conflict and would not nominate Trump for a Nobel Peace Prize.”

title: ‘All sorts of trouble’: Anika Wells’ expenses analysed
description: Sky News host James Macpherson analyses Communications Minister Anika Wells’ expenses.  “She’s in all sorts of trouble,” Mr Macpherson said.  “First, it emerged she paid, what was it? $94,000 to fly herself and a couple of staff members to New York.”

title: Barnaby Joyce made the move to One Nation for ‘all the wrong reasons’
description: Sky News host Peta Credlin highlights Barnaby Joyce’s move to One Nation from the Nationals Party.  “I worked closely with him … I like him as a human being,” Ms Credlin said.  “On this, I think he has made the wrong decision for all the wrong reasons.”

title: ‘Complete destruction’: Home after home destroyed in NSW bushfires
description: On tonight’s episode of Paul Murray Live, Sky News host Paul Murray discusses major bushfires in New South Wales, cost of living pressures, US politics and more.

title: US and Australia meet for ministerial meeting
description: Foreign Minister Penny Wong and Defence Minister Richard Marles are in Washington, DC, for annual talks with their American counterparts, US Secretary of State Marco Rubio and US Secretary of War Pete Hegseth.   The talks are expected to focus on AUKUS, China’s increasing influence in the region, and the signing of the critical minerals agreement.  The meeting between the four leaders coincides with the US conducting a review of AUKUS, which endorses the pact but calls for adherence to deadlines.  Mr Rubio says the US’s relationship with Australia is still incredibly strong, while Mr Marles says Australia’s relationship with the US is the most important and must be further worked on over the next 12 months.
